column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0049] Lead 40 includes an outer jacket 42 and a coiled stylet guide 46 positioned within a lumen formed by outer jacket 42.
#Text=Coiled stylet guide 46 may be formed by flat or cylindrical wires, which may be electrically conductive or nonconductive.
#Text=Outer jacket 42 may comprise an external diameter of approximately 0.045 to 0.055 inches (0.114 to 0.14 cm), and more preferably approximately 0.052 inches (0.13 cm).
#Text=Stylet guide 46 may comprise an external diameter of approximately 0.012 to 0.020 inches (0.03 to 0.05 cm), and more preferably approximately 0.016 inches (0.04 cm).
#Text=A set of conductors 45 wraps around stylet guide 46 to form one or more conductor coils 44.
#Text=In the illustrated embodiment, lead 40 comprises an octad lead with eight conductors included in set of conductors 45.
#Text=In other embodiments, lead 40 may comprise a quad lead including four electrodes or another type of lead including any number of electrodes.

#Text=[0050] In some embodiments, lead 40 provides enhanced stretchability to prevent lead failure, axial migration, anchor damage, and/or tissue damage at anchor points during typical patient movement.
#Text=Outer jacket 42 may be made of an extruded or molded material, e.g., a polyurethane material, with a substantially low durometer.
#Text=Conductors 45 may comprise braided strand wire (BSW) cables that provide increased flexibility.
#Text=[0051] Conductors 45 may be constructed as BSW cables wound into a helix.
#Text=Coiling or helically winding conductors 45 into conductor coil 44 allows conductors 45 to elongate or stretch as lead 40 experiences axial loading forces during use.
#Text=Helically wound conductors 45 may provide desirable axial compliance as well as needed bend-flex fatigue life.
#Text=In a case of severe buckling, the helically wound conductors 45 may collapse, binding the conductors and concentrating the bend into a small radius.
#Text=To address this problem, as described above, a reinforcement wire may be helically wound with the wound conductors 45 in a way that prevents bilateral collapse of the structure during buckling.
#Text=The wound reinforcement wire also may be helically extruded, forming a helical channel in which the conductors reside, as will be described in greater detail herein.
#Text=[0052] Coiled wire stylet guide 46 creates a lumen 47 to receive a stylet 48.
#Text=In some cases, stylet 48 comprises a wire with a diameter between approximately 0.012 inches and 0.01 inches (0.03 cm and 0.025 cm).
#Text=Stylet 48 may be inserted into lumen 47 of stylet guide 46 to steer lead 40 to a target site within a patient's body.
#Text=The coil design of stylet guide 46 eases the insertion and withdrawal of stylet 48 by forming a smooth path along which stylet 48 slides.
#Text=In addition, coiled wire stylet guide 46 may enhance steerability of lead 40, which increases accuracy when positioning lead 40 within a patient.
#Text=[0053] At a distal end of lead 40, not shown, stylet guide 46 may be sealed such that stylet 48 cannot extend beyond the distal end of lead 40.

#Text=Sealing the distal end of stylet guide 46 decreases the probability of inadvertently puncturing epidural tissue and causing a "wet tap," or cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) leak, which is an event that may cause severe headaches or, if the leak is severe, may cause neurological damage.
#Text=A CSF leak may occur if stylet 48 extends beyond stylet guide 46 into the epidural region proximate the spine of a patient, causing a puncture in the dura membrane of the epidural region.
